report_title: Online Perfume & Cosmetic Sales in the US
executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency.

Online beauty stores have been booming in recent years, with the growing popularity of e-commerce driving this growth. During the 2020 pandemic, social distancing regulation and stay-at-home orders pushed consumers to leverage online platforms to fulfill their shopping needs, swelling demand for online sellers of cosmetics and perfumes. During this time, consumers were spending less on eating out and transportation, causing disposable income to grow and boosting demand for discretionary products. However, recovering in-person shopping trends and unfavorable macroeconomic conditions in 2022 and 2023, including elevated inflation and consumer certainty, led to revenue losses, although these were insufficient to reverse pandemic gains. These trends will cause revenue to strengthen at an estimated CAGR of 11.4% to $48.1 billion through the end of 2024, including a 2.4% gain that year alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Macroeconomic Conditions Support Demand for Beauty Products
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Demand for cosmetics and fragrances is directly impacted by changes in macroeconomic conditions, including disposable income, consumer confidence levels, inflation and unemployment, as consumers cut back on spending when economic conditions are unfavorable. During the initial stages of the pandemic, consumers favored skincare products over cosmetics, as during this time, social distancing regulations and stay-at-home orders discouraged gatherings and events, discouraging consumers from using cosmetics as often.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Online sellers benefited from higher disposable income during the initial stages of the pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: This trend spilled over to 2021, largely because a reopening economy, rising disposable income and recovering consumer confidence boosted spending on beauty products. Revenue took a hit in 2022 and 2023 because elevated inflation raised consumer uncertainty and weakened disposable income, discouraging consumers from making discretionary purchases. This trend also represents stabilizing demand following the peaks of the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Low Barriers to Entry and Rising Demand Drive Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The growing popularity of e-commerce has pushed more online-only sellers into the industry. This trend proliferated during the initial stages of the pandemic, when consumers relied heavily on online shopping. Beauty products and fragrances include a broad range of products that appeal to consumers with different needs and preferences. This, alongside the low capital start-up costs, has facilitated many retailers entering the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Retailers Appeal to Younger Consumers by Adapting to Changing Consumer Preferences
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: To expand their market reach, retailers have concentrated on catering to previously underrepresented markets, focusing on consumers between the ages of 18 and 35. This includes carrying a broad range of products, including those that are popular in social media. Foreign cosmetic brands, particularly Asian beauty products, are becoming increasingly popular among domestic buyers. As consumers have become increasingly curious about foreign brands, retailers have kept them in stock to adapt to changing consumer preferences.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Carrying Male Cosmetic Has Become More Important for Sellers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Products created specifically for men's personal care routines (e.g., after-shaving care) are becoming more popular among consumers. Upstream manufacturers have focused on making them more attractive to consumers through packaging and marketing. Products with enhanced functionality, such as wrinkle-reducing moisturizers, have become increasingly prominent among male consumers, causing this market to expand.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Male buyers are more likely to buy products online
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Male buyers are more likely to buy products online than in brick-and-mortar stores, largely because of the standing stigmas surrounding beauty products for men. This allows men to generate higher sales volumes. In many cases, sellers with a strong male audience benefit from strong brand loyalty. By appealing to this underserved group, brands that focus on male beauty products can build a strong customer base.

Specialty brick-and-mortar beauty stores, such as Sally Beauty Supply and local beauty stores, pose an especially large threat to online-only sellers, particularly among buyers who favor customer service and prefer an in-person shopping experience. To compete with online sellers, traditional stores will increasingly focus on enhancing the in-person shopping experience by offering testers, in-store benefits and top-tier customer service.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: REVENUE WILL CONTINUE GROWING AT A SLOWER RATE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: - Online shopping will remain popular among consumers as many have grown accustomed to the convenience of e-commerce. Consumers will continue to buy beauty products from online sellers, although drastic gains are set to become less common. - Although inflation has slowed down, it remains above the Federal Reserve target rate. Elevated inflation will continue to mute demand for new cosmetics, slowing revenue growth. - Over the coming years, demand for online beauty product sellers will continue to grow, particularly as inflationary pressures lessen. Higher disposable income will allow consumers to buy non-necessity products, boosting makeup sales. - Smaller retailers will struggle to remain competitive in the coming years, largely because consumers increasingly favor larger brands with a strong online presence and favorable reputations.

- Retailers will continue curating their product offerings to match changing consumer preferences. By offering more antiaging products, retailers could reach a broader market. Over the coming years, online sellers will look to carry sustainable, cruelty-free and natural products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Appealing to Expanding and Evolving Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As a growing number of consumers become interested in organic products, the subsector will become more regulated, possibly standardizing the definition of organic cosmetics and boosting demand for them. In line with this trend, retailers will also continue to carry a broad range of imported beauty products, particularly those from Europe and Asia, as these are largely perceived to be of higher quality by customers. By adjusting their product offering, these sellers can appeal to more customers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Appealing to Expanding and Evolving Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As millennial shoppers account for a greater share of the workforce, they will continue demanding more and higher-value personal care products, including skincare and cosmetics with value-added properties, such as anti-aging or sun protection. Retailers that cater to this demographic by supplying youth-centric items, such as perfumes with light, fresh scents, are likely to outperform competitors. Another window of opportunity is the male market. Websites geared toward this demographic are likely to expand as these consumers continue to be more likely to turn to internet sales than brick-and-mortar alternatives.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: OTHER SELLERS WILL CONTINUE TO POSE A THREAT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Specialty brick-and-mortar beauty stores are the most significant source of competition for online sellers of beauty products. These stores continue to offer multiple value-added in-person services, such as the ability to try products and fragrances, superior customer service and salon services. To better compete with online sellers, brick-and-mortar stores are expanding to offer makeup classes and events to attract consumers who would typically purchase products online.

FAQs.answer: The PBA supports online cosmetic and fragrance sellers through advocacy, education and networking opportunities.
